items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: Although high spring tides remain until Monday morning, these will not reach Flood Alert level.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: Tides remain high for tonight's tide. Forecast high water is 21:30 on 08/10/21 with a level of 7.44 mAOD and a Force 1 Easterly wind. Tomorrow morningâ€™s tide is not forecast to reach flood alert thresholds. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not expected to flood at this point. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by midday, Saturday 09/10/2021.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 06:15 on 10/10/21 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 32 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 10/10/21, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses. Flooding is likely to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. With drier and more settled weather now forecast lake levels will slowly fall. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 10/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. There is no longer a threat of flooding. Following a period of high tides the next tides are not expected to reach the flood alert threshold. Astronomical spring tides peaked this afternoon and fluvial levels are now falling slowly.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Spring tides have peaked and water levels are falling. A flood alert is no longer required. This means the risk of spray, wave overtopping and minor flooding on low-lying land has reduced.

We do not expect to see further impacts for today's high tides.
While Saturday's High Tide levels will look high, they are below warning thresholds and are reducing further over the coming days.
The weather is remaining settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
Coastal conditions for the Wye estuary should ease for the 09/10/2021 high tide at 10:00am this morning.    
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
